concept.title: Introduction
concept.shortdesc: Structured documents provide the best, simplest and most reliable tools to write policy and procedure documents.

conbody.p: This is really written for someone writting or managing policy and procedure documents, and standards documents of any kind. These are usually maanged by dedicated teams, but the content comes from experts in their fields, who usually don't care to much about documenatation because their expertise lies in other areas.
Can the technology and technique called DITA help? Well, perhaps.

There are some very real advantages to trying DITA, and some real problems. If you are involved in managing standards, I think it could be well worth trying, but the existing literature seems to be written by
originators and implemetators of the specification, who are probably too close to it and are perhaps not aware of the specific needs of standards authors
consultants of various kinds, who might emphasise some of the benefits and less of the disadvantages, and who also try to solve unnecessary technical problems
technical writers in the specific fields of product documentation and, more especially computer software documentation, which is quite a different genre from standards, and focussed on irrelvant and (controversially) unhelpful techniques.
This short book was written in DITA. It was easy to write, but I'm not ware of its limitations too. Let's explore how it might, or might not help.
